I tried this in my pickup at night out in the wide open fields to communicate with guys in tractors that have good working cb's with tuned 4' antennas.  I would have been ecstatic if I got a 1 mile range and pleased enough to keep it if I got 1/4 to 1/2 mile range,  unfortunately this is not the case.  If you're looking for a radio to talk to the vehicle in front of you on the highway this will work.  If you're looking for a range of more than 1/16 of a mile look elsewhere....but not at the similar Midland offering, it's no better.

I wonder if the people who have so far reviewed "The Bard's Tale" (PC) on the web actually played it or the demo, or if they are relying on the reputation of previous games with the same name to make a judgment call about this game. I do not believe many did play it, because if they did, they would have seen how frustrating and how little fun the game becomes as it drags on. Yes, the voice acting is funny and enjoyable, but a cute and quirky story cannot make up for the game's overall poor design.

During certain animations (and more importantly during battle) the game will slow to a crawl comparable to the lag you might experience playing a newly released MMORPG on a dial-up connection. The slow down is a known problem for users of certain models of GeForce and Radeon cards, but not all users will be affected. As of the date of this review, there is no support for this issue and no official forum for discussion of such tech problems.

Don't rely on the game box and screenshots as a judge of the game environment. Basically we are dealing with a slightly modified, old fashioned top-down view with the added bonus of trees and other structures that must become transparent to allow you to see your character as you move under them. Due to the limited field of view, the minimap becomes essential to know what is a few feet away from you, either because you will not be able to actually see monsters until they are practically right on top of you or because they will be obscured if they move under trees that you are not under at the same moment.

Yes, you have companions that have cool powers that will be helpful in different situations. But no matter what you do, if you are ganged up on by more than three monsters at once, you may as well give up and load your game. This is because most of the monsters you fight have a tendency to knock you down or stun you for some time when they hit. Basically, if you cannot block perfectly, you will be round-robined to death as you enemy takes turns knocking you down and doing damage to you while you cannot stand up and recover. Meanwhile your companions will do whatever would be most illogical in such a situation: Healers will run forward and fight monsters with their fists, warriors will stop fighting in the middle of a battle and simply stand still, ranged weapon users will fire at monsters offscreen, drawing them into the battle.

Forget about the claim "less A, more I", the monsters aren't any better than most games...you will simply be overwhelmed with numbers in most cases.

Overall, the game is sub par...the price at release is low for a reason.

The merchant of Venice is Antonio, a depressive and self-sacrificing bachelor, madly devoted to his friend Bassanio. Bassanio wishes to marry Portia, a rich heiress, whose late father decreed in his will that any man who desires to marry his daughter must first partake in a trial - to choose between three caskets, one gold, the other silver and the last lead, each inscribed with an enigmatic saying. Whichever suitor is able to distinguish between inner and outer value and correctly chooses the casket which holds Portia's portrait will win her as his bride. Whoever chooses incorrectly, however, must remain a bachelor for life.

As the play opens Bassanio wishes to take his chances in order to win Portia's hand but does not have enough money to do so. The wealth of his friend Antonio is currently tied up in his ships now all off on lucrative commercial voyages. Until they return the two friends agree to ask a loan of the Jewish usurer Shylock. Shylock, the play's most famous character, is a vicious anti-Semitic stereotype. He despises Antonio because he is a Christian and because he lends money for free, reducing demand for Shylock's financial services ("were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will"). In an argument with his visitors, Shylock attempts to justify his usury by citing passages from the Bible but Antonio quickly warns Bassanio, "The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose." Shylock agrees to lend the Christians the requested amount on the condition that if the bond is forfeited Shylock will be entitled to a pound of Antonio's flesh. Finding such a forfeiture unlikely the Christians agree to these outrageous terms.

The play's subplots involve Shylock's daughter running away with a Christian suitor and Shylock's Christian servant comically parodying, with his blind father, the Biblical scene of the blind Isaac being deceived by his son Jacob (once again emphasizing the theme of the difference between inner and outer value). For Shylock, the  discovery of the loss of the money his daughter has run away with is even more painful to him than is the loss of his own daughter:

'My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter!
Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!
Justice! the law! my ducats, and my daughter!
A sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats,
Of double ducats, stolen from me by my daughter!
And jewels, two stones, two rich and precious stones,
Stolen by my daughter! Justice! find the girl;
She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.'

Act II, scene VIII; lines 15 - 22

Since this dialogue is first recited by a Christian claiming to be a witness to the scene we at first hope that this is simply the character's anti-Semitic slander but when Shylock himself appears on stage soon after, his attitude is confirmed: "I would my daughter were dead at my foot, and the jewels in her ear! would she were hearsed at my foot, and the ducats in her coffin!"

The play ends with a famous trial scene and an august speech on mercy. Does the play oppose the concepts of mercy and true inner value against an emphasis on legality and superficial values? Is Shakespeare suggesting that Shylock "the Jew" and his lack of mercy thus emanate from the false, legalistic and superficial values intrinsic in non-Christian, Jewish religion? It would appear so. Yet Shakespeare, always interested in the creation of psychological interiority, has given Shylock additional reasons for his murderous wrath. His famous "Hath not a Jew eyes?" speech has been embraced by those seeking to defend Shakespeare from the accusation of anti-Semitism, as has the extent of Antonio's bigoted crudities. Yet while the character of Shylock has his tragic foregrounding he is nonetheless a comedic and stereotypical bogeyman. He is not, like Sophocles' Electra, a hatred created by hatred, but a monster created by his own "sinful" Jewishness, propelled only further into rage by the Christian abuse his immorality and cupidity have instigated.

Could the poetic genius who, against all cultural precedent, created a noble, black African hero in "Othello" and the atheistic, humanistic cosmos of "King Lear" and whose Falstaff so ably decried false militaristic values, also have been capable of the narrowness of vision that created such a vicious ethnic stereotype with "The Merchant of Venice"? Jews were probably no more real for Shakespeare (they had been expelled from England in 1290 by King Edward I) than the Spartans seem to us but none of his other plays strike us as so morally alien to us as this one, not even the politically uncomfortable "Coriolanus." It seems unlikely that Shakespeare knew anything at all about the Talmud, the Oral Law or about the Pharisees aside from their role in the Gospels as one of Christ's primary spiritual opponents. With this background, it is perhaps not surprising that even a genius like Shakespeare could misinterpret the Jewish faith as 'legalistic' and immoral, but that he could not intuit the historical forces that constructed the association of Jews with usury is deeply unfortunate. Shakespeare was gifted beyond belief with the ability to see into reality with depth but could not recognize the historic forces that altered that reality, making today's social circumstances appear real and constant rather than being illusory constructs only of the moment. Thus we are left with a play in which Portia is a wise and merciful Christian lady who delightfully manages to 'out-literalize' the legalistic Shylock and thus crushes him, and one in which the synagogue is established as a place in which Jews come together in order to conspire to commit Christian murder.

The play is not without its charms. Many of the scenes are quite comic, the poetry handsome, the motif of the three caskets suggestive, the homoerotic source of Antonio's melancholy and devotion startlingly modern (and perhaps autobiographical?), the villain striking and menacing. But the world of the play, even when existing within the context of comedy, is unconvincing. Shylock, as stated above, is an unbelievable caricature and the idea that men would venture to Italy from all over the Mediterranean world and risk eternal bachelorhood in order to marry Portia, unconvincing. How exactly did Portia's father expect this outcome to be enforced, anyway? Fortunately, Shakespeare would go on to greater and wiser works.

I bought this coffeemaker in June 04. It worked consistently until May 05 when suddenly it fried (it had just finished brewing and was keeping a pot of coffee warm). Aside from the fact that it didn't last more than a year (my last coffeemaker lasted 5+) I would not buy this coffeemaker again.

First of all, pouring the water in is *very* tricky--instead of being large and in front, you have to aim in the back right, in a tiny hole. It's also hard to see where it's supposed to go because it's all black. I seriously had to pull it out and turn it every day in order to fill it with water; even still I spilled sometimes.

The lid on the carafe does not have any clasp to keep it on--it falls off if you don't hold on to it when pouring, and if it's not on *perfectly* when you brew, coffee spills all over. Of course, over time the lid gets more and more warped from the steam, so it becomes harder to get it to stay on.

The stainless steel never looked clean, no matter how often I worked on it. I think this had to do with the steam always condensing on the sides.

Finally, the coffee doesn't taste substantially better than any other coffeemakers I've tried. Good beans and fresh grinding matter more.
